Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Interactive Statistical Decision Trees for Application in Real-world Contexts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project involves improvement in the time and cost associated with training needed to prepare data analysts working in research fields outside of academia. Knowledge of statistical methods often does not translate to application to current research questions. The proposed project aims to reduce the time corporations and large and small organizations need in training new data analyst employees. Additionally, the project aims to reduce errors in judgment regarding the application of appropriate statistical tests to particular problems. Commercially, the project may replace libraries of statistical reference manuals utilized to make decisions about application of statistical models.

This I-Corps project leverages academic research in statistics to application in real-world research contexts such as data analysis in medical research centers. The project is designed to assist quantitative data analysts in moving from hypothesis to interpretation of statistical results through a simple series of decision steps, using parameters known to analysts across a variety of contexts. The prototype was built using a puzzle/maze typology. Current market available tools are limited in scope of statistical tests, and do not provide demonstration of the test in action with hypothetical data. The current project prototype covers 28 different parametric and non-parametric statistical tests appropriate across all four quantitative data types: categorical, ordinal, interval, and ratio-level data. Additionally, the current prototype provides demonstration of all 28 tests via video-link using sample data, provide output results, and demonstration of appropriate reporting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Texas at San Antonio
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas at San Antonio

POR.DRECONTENT:
Abstract: The Stat Tree NSF I-Corps team has explored the commercialization potential of a web-based interactive statistical decision tree developed by the technical lead (PI) at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA). Prototype development and utilization among students enrolled in research methods courses at UTSA over the course of several years and including the grant award period demonstrated the potential for reducing training time and increasing confidence and efficiency in the selection, testing and analysis of statistics for any given research question. The Stat Tree team set out to discover if real gains could be made in research production for organizations outside the classroom.

Intellectual Merit: Supported by this NSF I-Corps program, the potential market needs for a web-based interactive statistical decision tree has been surveyed by this team, through a rigorous customer discovery process at top medical research facilities and related industries. A key outcome of this I-Corps program for the team was the understanding of potential market segments to improve chances for commercialization of software that can be profitable and sustainable. After more than 125 interviews across the country, the team identified the most feasible market segment for Stat Tree software among early and mid-career data analysts. The team also identified needs for further development of the prototype for a minimum viable product. Results of customer discovery interviews indicated that potential growth for this product increases significantly with further development. Corroborating evidence including market share of related products, as well as future job market analysis among data analysts from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, indicate further development of the prototype could yield significantly greater potential for the product. This development has the potential to advance knowledge regarding different approaches to analyzing quantitative data.

Broader Impact: This NSF I-Corps project has the potential to increase public scientific literacy in the use of statistical techniques to analyze quantitative data. Applied to early career data analysts and employing organizations, the project can reduce research production time by over 20%. This improved efficiency in research production can benefit society by providing more timely answers to pressing questions, such as reducing the amount of time in making medical discoveries. On a smaller scale, the I-Corps training has allowed the technical lead to envision the teaching of applied research methods at the undergraduate and graduate level, to further advance educational approaches which contribute to the development of a diverse, globally competitive, quantitatively-oriented workforce with a new set of marketable skills. Additionally, the Entrepreneurial Lead (a Hispanic minority, graduate student) developed improved abilities in understanding and conducting the process of customer discovery interviewing, and its concomitant techniques.


Last Modified: 11/07/2019
Modified by: H P Leblanc
